Met de stijgende levensverwachting en het vervagen van pensioenregelingen in zowel publieke als particuliere sectoren, begint het begrip ‘pensioen’ steeds meer voor meer mensen van belang te worden. Voor veel mensen brengt deze verantwoordelijkheid van pensioenbeleggingen grote zorgen met zich mee.

In een tijd waarin de beurzen de grenzen verleggen, is het nu van cruciaal belang dat pensioensparen wordt beschouwd als een investering. De meesten begrijpen wel dat sparen voor hun pensioen een noodzakelijkheid is, maar men begrijpt niet goed waarom het zo belangrijk is. En net als bij elke andere investering komt het met grote risico’s.

Met deze blogpost bespreken we de risico’s van pensioenbeleggingen en waarom het onvermijdelijk is, ongeacht het risico. Laten we eerst het verschil tussen risico-aversie en risicovolle beleggingen begrijpen.

Riskovolle beleggingen zijn situaties waarbij de potentiële opbrengsten hoger zijn dan de risico’s. Het is een soort kans om in een relatief korte periode veel meer winst te behalen dan in situaties waar het risico eerder laag is. Bij pensioenbeleggingen wil je kiezen voor een beleggingsstrategie die een goede balans biedt tussen rendement en risico.

Een goede pensioenbeleggingsstrategie heeft veel risico-aversie. Dit betekent dat men op zoek gaat naar beleggingen met lage risico’s en lagere verwachte rendementen in plaats van te speculeren met de kans om een veel hogere winst te behalen.

Er zijn veel verschillende soorten beleggingen die een goede balans bieden tussen rendement en risico. Bijvoorbeeld, als je een conservatief belegger bent, zou je kunnen kiezen voor obligaties of staatsfondsen in plaats van aandelen. Als je echter een meer risicovol belegger bent, zou je kunnen kiezen voor obligaties met een hogere rente of een vermogensfonds dat actief beleggen omvat.

Ook als je een aandeelhouder bent, kan het nuttig zijn om je beleggingsportefeuille zo te diversifiëren dat je blootstelling krijgt aan verschillende sectoren, industrieën en regio’s. Door je beleggingen goed te diversifiëren, kun je je risico’s verminderen door kortetermijnvolatiliteit te verminderen.

Beleggingen zijn ook noodzakelijk omdat ze het vermogen bieden om je koopkracht te verhogen. Wanneer de rente laag is, verschijnen er meer mogelijkheden om te beleggen. Meer beleggers krijgen toegang tot lagere kosten, met het mogelijke rendement als resultaat. Bovendien kunnen beleggingen helpen om de inflatie te bestrijden, waardoor je koopkracht gedurende je pensioen toe te nemen.

Tot slot, maar minstens zo belangrijk, is het belang van pensioenbeleggingen als het gaat om het bouwen van een financieel kussen en het verstrekken van financiële zekerheid. Met een goed

Caroline Ellison, the former CEO of a now-defunct cryptocurrency derivatives exchange, told a judge on Tuesday that she was “truly sorry” for defrauding customers of her company, FTX, out of millions of dollars.

"I knew that what I was doing was wrong,” Ellison told U.S. District Judge William O'Grady as she was sentenced in the Eastern District of New York.

Ellison, 31, pleaded guilty in April to wire fraud and operating an unlicensed money transmitting business. Prosecutors say Ellison engaged in a scheme to defraud customers of FTX, a cryptocurrency derivatives exchange she co-founded with her husband in 2017, of at least $3 million.

According to the U.S. Attorney’s Office, between December 2017 and December 2020, Ellison and others used their access to FTX customers’ accounts to manipulate their prices and artificially inflate the value of FTX’s cryptocurrency-based contracts. Ellison then allegedly used the proceeds to purchase luxury items, including real estate in her husband’s name, and funded her own personal bank accounts and cryptocurrency wallets.

“This was not an ordinary criminal case,” Judge O’Grady said in court. “It involved the use of technology to perpetrate the fraud. It was a serious crime and it was a bold crime.”

As part of her plea agreement, Ellison will pay back all of the money she stole from FTX customers and agreed to cooperate with the investigation. She also agreed to a three-year supervised release and to pay a $5,000 fine.

Ellison expressed her remorse for her actions and asked for leniency. “I have taken complete responsibility for my actions,” she said. “I am truly sorry for what I have done.”

Judge O'Grady accepted Ellison’s plea and sentenced her to two years in prison, followed by three years of supervised release.

“The court must take seriously the crime that was committed and impose a sentence that sends a message that those who engage in this type of behavior will be held accountable,” O'Grady said.

The sentence serves as a stern warning to those who engage in fraudulent activities in the cryptocurrency space. It is clear that the U.S. government is cracking down on anyone who attempts to defraud investors, customers and the public.

“The sentence handed down to Ms. Ellison should serve as a cautionary tale to those tempted to engage in cryptocurrency fraud,” said U.S. Attorney David Weiss. “We remain committed to prosecuting those who seek to take advantage of our markets for their own personal gain.”

The case against Ellison is part of an ongoing effort by the U.S. government to crack down on cryptocurrency fraud. In recent months, several other individuals have been charged with similar crimes, and the U.S. Department of Justice is actively investigating a number of other potential cryptocurrency fraud cases.

Cryptocurrency fraud is a major issue in the industry, and the U.S. government is taking it very seriously. Those who engage in these types of activities should know that they will face serious repercussions, as Ellison’s sentence shows.

Aspirin and Lispernol belong to different classes of medications and they may have potential drug interactions when taken together. Aspirin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) and Lispernol is a beta blocker. Beta blockers, like Lispernol, are commonly used to treat high blood pressure and other heart conditions. They work by blocking the effects of certain hormones and chemicals in the body that can constrict blood vessels and increase blood pressure.  Aspirin may interfere with the effectiveness of Lispernol in lowering blood pressure. Additionally, taking aspirin and Lispernol together may increase the risk of bleeding and other side effects.  It is important to discuss any concerns about your medication regimen with your healthcare provider. They will be able to advise you on the best course of treatment based on your specific situation and medical history. Gold steadied on Tuesday, with a firmer U.S. dollar capping the metal's advance.

Spot gold was down 0.2 percent at $1,865.05 per ounce by 11:20 a.m. ET (1620 GMT). U.S. gold futures gained 0.1 percent to $1,866.40.

The dollar index, a measure of the greenback against a basket of six currencies, rose 0.2 percent. A stronger dollar makes gold costlier for holders of other currencies.

The Federal Reserve is widely expected to maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy at the conclusion of a two-day policy meeting later in the day.

"Gold prices have been hampered a bit today by a little bit of dollar strength, but overall I think that prices have been range bound," said Michael Matousek, head trader at U.S. Global Investors.

"Until the FOMC announcement later this afternoon we're likely to see gold hold onto these gains," he added.

The focus remained on the uncertainty surrounding the likely outcome of Britain's exit from the European Union. An agreement is still unlikely before the end of the year, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Monday.

Elsewhere, the market is eyeing the U.S. Senate's second impeachment trial of President Donald Trump.

Demand for safe-haven assets could weaken if the Democrats succeed in their effort to convict Trump and removing him from office.

Holdings of SPDR Gold Trust, the world's largest gold-backed exchange-traded fund, fell 0.20 percent to 1,219.77 tonnes on Monday.

Gold prices are expected to remain supported in the near term, with U.S. stimulus set to remain in focus.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said he is ready to move ahead with the $900 billion COVID-19 stimulus package if an agreement can be reached.

The Senate had voted to give final approval to the measure, a version of which had been approved by the House of Representatives on Monday.

Elsewhere, silver fell 0.2 percent to $25.05 per ounce, while platinum gained 0.7 percent to $1,063.50. Palladium fell 0.6 percent to $2,384.50.

For example, if one owner contributes $100,000 towards the purchase of a $500,000 property, their ownership percentage would be calculated as follows: $100,000 / $500,000 = 20%.It's important to note that the ownership percentage can also be affected by any mortgage payments or other debts on the property. text: But what if I am getting paid salary from a source in India? In other words, it may be that in India a research assistant at a college on average earns a third of what a research assistant like me earns here in US. In that case, even if my cost of living there is much less, so is my salary. There are sites that provide a good guidance for what the average salary for an profession with x years of experience would be. Of course some would get paid more than average. So you can try and make a logic, if in US say you are being paid more than average, you would be paid more than average elsewhere. Plus If moving from Developed to Developing country, one has the Advantage of positive pedigree bias.  There are also websites that would give the Purchasing Power Parity for quite a few currency pairs. The Real difficulty to find is whether the Lifestyle you have in a specific country would be similar in other country. If you compare like for like it becomes slightly skewed. If you compare equivalence, then can you adjust.  A relevant example my friend in US had a Independent Bungalow in US. It was with Basement and attic, 2 levels of living space with 4 bedroom. He shifted to India and got a great salary compared to normal Indian salary. However this kind of house in India in Bangalore would be affordable only to CEO's of top companies. So is living in a 3 room apartment fine? There are multiple such aspects. Drinking a Starbucks coffee couple of times a day is routine for quite a few in US. In India this would be considered luxury. A like for equivalent comparison is "One drinks 3-4 mugs of Coffee" in US, and average Indian drinks "Tea/Coffee 3-4 mugs". In India the local Tea / Coffee would be Rs 10 - Rs 20. A Starbucks would come with starting price of Rs 150. The same applies to food. A McBurger in India would be around Rs 100. The Indian equivalent Wada Pav is for Rs 10. A Sub Way would be Rs 150. A Equivalent Mumbai Sandwich around Rs 25. I personally am picky about food, so it doesn't matter where I go, I can only eat specific things, which means I spend a huge amount of money if I am outside of India. When I was in US, I couldn't afford a maid, driver or any help. In India I have 2 maids, a cooking maid and a driver. Plus I get plumber, electrician, window cleaner, and all the help without costing me much. Things that I absolutely can't dream in US. My colleague in UK preferred to stay in a specific locality as it has a very good Church. So if its important, one may find few good ones in India if one is Roman Catholic, if one follows Lutheran, Greek Orthodox, tough luck.  Citizenship: Does it matter ... A foreign national may never get an Indian citizenship. Children don't qualify either unless both parents are Indian. Health Care: Again is quite different. One may feel Health care in US is not good or very expensive ... but there are multiple aspects of this. So in essence its very broad there is traffic, cleanliness, climate, culture, etc ... PS: A research assistant in India is poorly paid, because colleges don't have funds. Research in fundamental science is quite low. Industry to university linkages are primitive and now where close to what we have in US.

text:
BRUSSELS (Reuters) - Internet providers have warned that European Union plans to make Big Tech companies cover their costs of providing basic internet services could push up prices and create market distortions.

The plans, which are part of the EU's so-called Digital Services Act and are still being discussed, would require Big Tech companies like Google and Facebook to pay a share of the costs of providing basic internet services such as access to websites or streaming services.

The idea is that, since Big Tech companies make large profits from using the public internet, they should also contribute to the cost of the infrastructure that makes that possible.

However, internet providers have warned that such a plan could put an undue burden on them and could force them to pass on the costs to customers.

"Any proposals to impose costs on internet providers will have a direct and significant effect on the cost of our services and on the competitiveness of the European digital economy," said Malcolm Johnson, director-general of the GSMA, which represents mobile operators around the world.

"We are concerned that there is a risk that the Digital Services Act could lead to price increases for consumers and market distortions," he added.

The warnings come after the European Commission published its long-awaited proposal for a new Digital Services Act, which would give companies such as Google and Facebook much greater responsibility for the services they provide online.

The Commission has proposed making companies pay a share of the costs associated with providing basic internet services, such as access to websites or streaming services.

The Commission has yet to specify exactly what percentage of the costs the companies would be expected to pay, but it is believed that the figure could be around 5-10%.

Internet providers argue that such a plan would disproportionately affect them, as it would require them to pay for services that are provided for free to Big Tech companies.

"It is also essential that there is no duplication of costs or inappropriate cross-subsidisation from one sector of the industry to another," said Johnson.

The internet providers also argue that such a plan would distort the market and could lead to Big Tech companies gaining an unfair competitive advantage over their smaller competitors.

"The cost of providing basic internet services should be the same for everyone and the competitive landscape should remain fair and balanced," said Johnson.

The plans have also been criticised by consumer groups, who argue that it could lead to higher internet bills for consumers.

"Any proposal that shifts costs from Big Tech to consumers or small business would be unacceptable," said Sören Scholz, Director of EU Affairs at consumer rights organisation BEUC.

The Digital Services Act is still being discussed and no final decisions have been taken. However, the warnings from internet providers are likely to be taken seriously by the Commission, as they could have a significant impact on how the market develops.

The Republican bid to control the Pennsylvania House of Representatives ended in failure on Monday as Democrats voted to elect a Speaker and pass a budget that would prevent a government shutdown.

The historic vote, which would deny the GOP a veto-proof majority in the chamber, came after weeks of intense debate and party politics.

The newly elected Speaker, Democrat Joe Markosek, secured the support of the majority of his Democratic colleagues and some Republicans in a 101-94 vote.

Markosek, who has served as the top Democrat in the chamber since 2011, acknowledged the gravity of the moment.

“This is an historic vote for the people of Pennsylvania,” he said. “This is a vote to end the ideological battles that have paralyzed our House and now we can get to the business of governing.”

The budget that was passed includes a $32.3 billion spending plan that includes no new taxes and a $1.8 billion tax package. It increases funding for schools, combat opioids and cuts $500 million in regulations.

It also gives pay raises to state employees, addresses the state’s pension crisis and brings an end to the state’s four-year impasse over a budget.

The vote disappointed Republicans who had hoped to gain a majority after Democrats had held it for decades.

Rep. Mike Turzai, the Republican leader in the House, said he was disappointed in the vote, but said it was time to move on.

“It is clear from today’s vote that the Democrats have the votes to win the speakership and govern this House,” he said. “But now is the time for the elected leadership to find common ground, get serious about government and get to work for the people of Pennsylvania.”

The vote also signals a shift in the balance of power in Harrisburg, where the GOP has held sway in recent years. Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat, has seen his own agenda stymied by a Republican-controlled House and Senate.

Wolf praised the House for ending the gridlock and said he was looking forward to working with the new Speaker and House leadership.

“This budget is an historic step forward that reflects the values and priorities of Pennsylvanians,” he said. “The people of Pennsylvania deserve a government that works for them, and this budget will help ensure that.”

The budget will now go to the Senate, which is also controlled by Republicans, for approval.

The battle for the speakership was marked by infighting among Republicans, and some Democrats had expressed worries that a prolonged power struggle could lead to a government shutdown.

But with the vote to select a speaker, the House ended its five-month standoff and paved the way for the General Assembly to pass a budget before the end of June.

text:
Private payrolls increased more than expected in December, the ADP National Employment Report showed Thursday.

Private payrolls surged by 235,000 jobs in December, compared with an increase of 108,000 in November, and well above the consensus estimate of 145,000. The strong gain marked the seventh consecutive month of growth in private sector employment, and the largest gain since June of last year.

The report also showed that the services sector added 199,000 jobs in December, while the goods-producing sector added 36,000 jobs. Manufacturing employment rose by 20,000 in December, the fourth straight month of gains.

The job market in the US remains robust and has now recovered more than half of the 22 million jobs lost in March and April due to the coronavirus pandemic. Since then, job growth has averaged nearly 3 million per month, and the unemployment rate has fallen from a peak of 14.7% in April to 6.7% in November.

"The job market closed out 2020 on a strong note, with job growth remaining solid and outstripping expectations," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics.

"Gains are broad-based across industries and company sizes. Much of the job growth is coming from companies that benefitted from the pandemic, such as those in professional and business services, leisure and hospitality and health care," Zandi said.

However, he noted that the report shows there are still large job losses in some industries, such as retail and hospitality.

"The labor market is clearly healing but it still has a long way to go to repair the damage inflicted by the pandemic," Zandi said.

The government will release its December jobs report Friday, which is expected to show that nonfarm payrolls increased by 75,000 in December, according to economists surveyed by Dow Jones. The unemployment rate is expected to remain unchanged at 6.7%.

The ADP report showed that small businesses added 101,000 jobs in December, while medium-sized businesses added 92,000 and large businesses added 42,000. The leisure and hospitality industry added 35,000 jobs, while professional and business services added 51,000 and trade, transportation and utilities added 18,000.

Economists say the recovery in the labor market has likely been supported by the federal government's massive stimulus packages. The $900 billion aid package passed in December provided direct payments to individuals, additional unemployment benefits and aid to small businesses.

"The labor market recovery is being supported by a wide array of government stimulus measures, including the December relief package," said Gus Faucher, chief economist at PNC Financial Services Group. "However, the economic recovery could slow as the virus continues to spread and as the expected surge in new infections from holiday travel becomes more visible in the coming weeks."

2022 has been a year of unprecedented growth for the stock market. After seeing a historic bull run in the first half of the year, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average both had their best year since the Great Recession of 2008. Stocks continued to rise throughout the rest of the year, despite major economic events like the US-China trade war and political unrest in Washington.

The major indices started the year with strong growth and continued to climb, even with occasional downturns. The S&P 500 gained over 20 percent in the first six months, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose just as much. Both reached record highs in June before retreating a bit in the second half of the year.

This unprecedented stock market growth is largely attributed to massive amounts of stimulus provided by governments and central banks throughout the year. The US Congress passed several relief bills in 2020 and early 2021 that provided over $4 trillion in economic relief. The Federal Reserve also made numerous cuts to interest rates to make money cheaper for businesses and consumers.

The effect of the stimulus was immediate. Industries like technology, biotechnology, and banking all saw huge gains from the market, as investors bet on the economic recovery and the booming new industries that were emerging. Tech stocks were also helped by the increased demand for products and services from new tech-driven businesses. These products and services have become more essential as people continue to work, learn, and play at home.

In addition to tech stocks, the healthcare sector was also one of the top performers in 2022. Companies in this sector continued to benefit from the pandemic, as medical products and services continue to be in high demand. Healthcare stocks gained close to 30 percent for the year.

The rising stock market also caused home prices to surge. In the first half of the year, the average sale price of homes nationwide reached a record high. The booming housing market can be attributed to low interest rates, increased consumer confidence, and rising wages.

Overall, the stock market’s performance in 2022 was a positive sign that the economy is continuing to recover from the pandemic-driven recession of 2020. While there were some minor hiccups throughout the year, the markets were largely resilient, as evidenced by the strong gains in the major indices.

As investors look ahead to the rest of the year, most experts are cautiously optimistic. "I don't think there is any real risk of a crash in the stock market," he said. "If we can get past the current health crisis, then I think there is good reason to expect another strong year for stocks. I think we should see healthy returns."

"We should expect to see some periods of volatility in the markets this year, but I don’t think it will be anything major," he said. "I think the key for investors is to stay disciplined and stay focused on the long-term."

The new year’s gains were driven by optimism over new vaccine developments and hopes of economic recovery in 2021.

“We’ve been expecting a risk-on environment and with the market gains on the first day of trading, investors are clearly sensing there is more upside potential than downside,” said Tom Cahill, managing director of investments at Vanguard.

“After 2020, it’s a sign of optimism that investors have the appetite to jump in on the first day of 2021,” said Sam Stovall, chief investment strategist at CFRA. “We did see some impressive relative strength in the market in December despite all the uncertainty, and that carried into 2021.”

“The combination of both Pfizer and Moderna, and their relative efficacy, are really driving sentiment here,” said Peter Boockvar, chief investment officer of Bleakley Advisory Group.

Tech stocks led the charge higher, driven in part by investors’ search for momentum. Apple, Amazon and Tesla all soared on the first day of trading, up more than 2.4%, 1.8%, and 2.5%, respectively.

text: True randomness is n't possible for a processor , since it 's always just running input - > some function - > output . But there are functions that behave ' almost randomly ' . A ( bad , but easy to understand ) example is the following method for generating a random 5 - digit number : * Start with any 5 - digit number . Let 's say 12345 . * Square it . 12345 ^ 2 = 152399025 * Take the middle 5 digits : 15**23990**25 * Our next ' random ' number is 23990 . Then to generate another one , we repeat the process . Our next number in this case would be 55201 , then 71504 , 28220 , etc . Now , this turns out to be a bad example , because it will always collapse down to a cycle or a repeated number at some point . But there are more mathematically - sophisticated methods that are better behaved .

text: Fundamental analysis is a method of evaluating the intrinsic value of a stock by examining its financial statements and other company-specific factors. One financial metric that is often used in fundamental analysis is the price-to-earnings-to-growth (PEG) ratio.The PEG ratio is calculated by dividing the price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio by the company's expected earnings growth rate. The P/E ratio is a measure of the price of a stock relative to its earnings per share. It is calculated by dividing the current market price of the stock by the company's earnings per share (EPS). The PEG ratio is used to evaluate whether a stock is overvalued or undervalued based on its price and earnings growth.For example, if a company has a P/E ratio of 20 and an expected earnings growth rate of 10%, its PEG ratio would be 2. A PEG ratio of less than 1 is generally considered undervalued, while a PEG ratio greater than 1 is considered overvalued.There are several limitations to using the PEG ratio as a sole measure of a stock's value. It is based on future earnings growth estimates, which are inherently uncertain and subject to change. Additionally, the PEG ratio does not take into account other factors that can affect a company's value, such as its debt levels, market conditions, and competitive landscape. It is important to consider a variety of factors when evaluating a stock and to use the PEG ratio as just one tool among many in your analysis.

Moscow (Reuters) - Russia's central bank said on Wednesday it has frozen $488 million worth of assets owned by Linde, the world's largest industrial gases company, following a lawsuit filed by Sweden's Swedbank against the company.

The asset freeze was imposed after a criminal case was opened against the company and other parties in connection with a complex international fraud investigation, according to a statement from the Central Bank.

The statement said the decision was taken after the Sweden's state prosecutor informed the Russian authorities about the Swedbank investigation.

It added that the freezing of the assets would remain in effect for three months, pending the outcome of the investigation.

Swedbank filed the suit in August, accusing Linde of involvement in a multi-billion dollar fraud involving several banks and companies.

According to the suit, Swedish authorities have identified three individuals who had organized a complex fraud that defrauded Swedbank out of over $1 billion in 2018.

Linde, which has denied any wrongdoing, said at the time that it was cooperating fully with authorities and would provide all necessary documentation to investigate the matter.

Linde said it was confident that it had acted in accordance with applicable law and regulations and that it was not party to any criminal activity.

The fraud scheme involved a number of banks, including UBS, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and Barclays, as well as other companies, including Linde.

The scheme involved the fraudulent transfer of money to accounts belonging to shell companies, which were then allegedly used to purchase luxury cars, among other assets.

Swedbank said it had filed claims against several of the individuals and entities involved in the scheme, including Linde, but had not yet received a satisfactory response from the company.

The central bank said that it had also imposed a temporary freeze on assets owned by a number of other companies and individuals who had been linked to the fraud scheme.

The move comes as the Russian government steps up efforts to crack down on financial crime, particularly international money laundering schemes.

The government has vowed to take measures to prevent similar schemes from happening in the future, including tougher regulations and increased supervision of financial activities.

The central bank said it would continue to monitor the situation and take further action if necessary.

The freezing of assets owned by Linde is the latest example of Russia's growing determination to tackle financial crime.

It is also the first time that Russia has frozen assets of a foreign company as part of a fraud investigation.

The $488 million frozen represents just a fraction of Linde's global assets, which have been valued at $25.8 billion.

It remains to be seen how the situation will unfold and what the outcome of the investigation will be.

In the meantime, the asset freeze will remain in place, meaning that Linde will not be able to access or use the frozen funds.

Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao has said that customer deposits are starting to come back into the crypto exchange following its $40 million security breach earlier this year, but the road ahead will be “bumpy.”

Speaking at the Asia Blockchain Summit in Taipei, Taiwan, Zhao said that the firm’s losses were “not negligible” and that it had to “restructure certain teams and business units” after the attack.

The attack, which occurred in May, saw hackers able to steal 7,000 Bitcoins (BTC) from Binance’s hot wallet. At the time, the value of the stolen cryptocurrency was about $40 million, however, its price has since risen to around $69 million.

Zhao said that as a result, Binance had to take action to protect its customers. “We had to take some temporary measures such as limiting deposits and withdrawals, and doing additional user verifications,” he said.

However, he added that the firm had implemented a number of security measures to help protect user funds and prevent similar incidents in the future. “We beefed up our security, we introduced enhanced 2FA, we started doing KYC [Know Your Customer] checks and anti-fraud checks,” Zhao said.

He also said that the firm has been making progress on its insurance fund, which is designed to protect users’ funds in the event of a security breach. “We’ve slowly been building up our insurance fund and so far it looks like it’s working really well,” he said.

Overall, Zhao said that customer deposits have started to come back, but the road ahead was still “bumpy.”

“We’re definitely making progress on recovering customer deposits, so that’s one bright spot,” he said. “But I think the road ahead is still bumpy and we need to be very mindful of how we spend our resources and how we re-allocate our resources.”

Despite the attack, Binance has continued to grow and expand its services. In October, it launched its own crypto debit card and a new trading platform targeting institutional investors.

Zhao said that Binance was also looking to roll out a new “decentralized” platform. “We’re trying to build a decentralized exchange,” he said. “So we’re looking at a hybrid approach where the customer side is still centralized, but the back end is decentralized.”

In addition, Zhao said that the company was looking to expand into other areas beyond just crypto. “We’re actually looking into doing some other services, such as staking, decentralized finance, and other services to our users,” he said.

Overall, Zhao said that the firm was doing well and was looking to the future. “We’re still very bullish about the cryptocurrency industry and our role in it,” he said. “We’re definitely making progress on recovering customer deposits and so far it looks like it’s working really well.”

text: Fortunately , we did n't start out with just two humans . In evolution , it does n't work , like , one member of the species evolves into a new species , and then that individual onward is the forerunner of the entire species . Entire groups evolve at the same time . Let 's take the proverbial chicken and egg , for example . Somewhere a group of proto - chickens lived in the same region and interbred with each other . As they did , they exchanged DNA , and certain traits became common . Eventually the group became genetically enough that they became chickens and are a separate species from the original proto - chickens . This same principal is how humans evolved as well . A population of Homo heidelbergensis in evolved into Homo sapiens , while a population in Europe evolved into Homo sapiens neanderthalensis , and another in Asia became the Denisovans . These separate populations of the same species evolved as a group , independently from each other , to best suit their habitats . Of course , Homo sapiens came out of Africa , interbred with both Neanderthals and Denisovans , and produced different varieties of our species , Homo sapiens sapiens .

text: The United States is a sovereign country and, as such, is not subject to the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice (ICJ), which is the primary judicial branch of the United Nations and the world's highest international court. The ICJ has jurisdiction over disputes between states, but it does not have the power to hear cases involving individual countries without their consent.  The United States has not ratified the Optional Protocol to the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations, which gives the ICJ jurisdiction to hear cases brought by one state against another. As a result, the United States is not bound by the ICJ's decisions and cannot be sued at the court without its consent.  It is worth noting that the United States has participated in some cases before the ICJ and has accepted the court's jurisdiction in certain limited circumstances, such as when it has agreed to submit to the court's jurisdiction as part of a treaty or other international agreement. However, the United States has not accepted the ICJ's jurisdiction to hear cases involving its conduct as a sovereign state.

LOS ANGELES, CA – Gabrielle Union “felt entitled” to straying from her first marriage, she revealed in a recently taped episode of the “Red Table Talk” on Facebook Watch.

The actress, who has been married to NBA superstar Dwyane Wade since 2014, opened up to hosts Jada Pinkett Smith and Adrienne Banfield-Jones, discussing the difficulties in being honest during her first marriage.

Union, 46, married producer Chris Howard in 2001. The marriage ended in divorce five years later and Union confessed on the show she had been unfaithful to Howard during their relationship.

“This would have been my first marriage,” Union said. “I was still naïve enough to think that people who are supposed to love you aren’t supposed to hurt you, and when they do, you’re supposed to leave.”

Union went on to discuss why she felt “entitled” to break her vows.

“I felt like I deserved happiness,” she explained. “I was like ‘Well, what do I do? How do I do it?’ I felt entitled to whatever happiness I could find.”

Union acknowledged she was a “selfish” partner, saying her marriage wasn’t her only transgression.

“I was a terrible, terrible partner and like I said, it wasn’t just the cheating. It was a bunch of things that were to say the least pretty narcissistic and pretty selfish and probably pretty tragic,” she said.

Though she didn’t say who she strayed with, Union did confirm to Pinkett Smith that it wasn’t a long-term affair.

“That one wasn’t a relationship, no,” she said.

Union also discussed her use of drugs, particularly marijuana and cocaine, during her late teens and early twenties.

“I was a drugged out chaotic mess. I was doing drugs, I was partying, I was not showing up for work, I was stealing from work, I was doing all kinds of crazy stuff,” Union said. “I was a wild child.”

Union said it wasn’t until she reached her thirties that she found her calling.

“It was almost like the light switch just flicked on,” Union said. “Suddenly I was like ‘Oh, this is what I’m supposed to be doing.'”

Union revealed that it was the work that allowed her to channel her creativity and ultimately saved her life.

“For me to find a place to channel my chaos and all of my energy, it was the best decision that I could have ever made,” Union said.

Union has since gone on to become one of the most visible and successful actors in Hollywood with a long list of credits that include her stint as a judge on America’s Got Talent and her role in the film Breakin’ All the Rules.

Union’s “Red Table Talk” episode airs Thursday.

text:
.

The concept of trying to time the markets is one of the oldest, and one of the most often debated, in investing. With the S&P 500 up 13.5% this year and all of the major averages up substantially, it would seem that timing the markets has worked.

But those who have tried have often come up short. According to data from Bespoke Investment Group, the five biggest one-day losses for the S&P 500 in 2020 account for more than 80% of the index's overall losses for the year. And if you removed the worst day of the year—March 12, when the index fell 9.5%—it would be up 14.5%, instead of 13.5%.

In other words, if you didn't own the market on five days this year, you probably had a much better year than if you were constantly trading in and out. That's not to say that the market isn't volatile, or that it isn't worth trading—but it is a reminder that those who attempt to time the markets are often taking on too much risk.

The five worst days of 2020, in terms of the S&P 500 losses, were March 12 (-9.5%), September 3 (-5.6%), October 8 (-4.4%), June 11 (-4.4%) and December 21 (-4.1%). All told, those five days have accounted for more than 83% of the total losses for the S&P 500 in 2020.

It's no surprise, then, that the market has been relatively stable this year, despite a variety of geopolitical tensions, a pandemic, and a contentious presidential election. While there have been brief pullbacks on some days, the market has mostly seen gains, particularly since the April low.

This illustrates one of the oldest investing maxims: buy and hold. If you buy into an index fund and simply sit tight, the odds are good that you'll end up with positive returns in the long run. As 2020 has shown us, those who try to time the markets are more likely to end up with losses.

That doesn't mean there isn't a place for trading or investing strategies, but it does mean that you should approach them with caution. With the S&P 500 up for the year, and with such a large chunk of the losses being concentrated in just five days, it's clear that timing the markets isn't as easy as it might seem.

Those five days were very turbulent and the market had a lot of uncertainty surrounding it. It is easy to see why trying to time the markets was not a successful endeavor. Investors should take away a lesson from this year's market experience: market timing is often a risky endeavor, and it can lead to large losses.

It's important to understand that investing is a long-term game, and that you should focus on factors like quality of earnings, valuations, and macroeconomic trends. If you're investing, take a long-term approach, and make sure you're diversified and comfortable with the level of risk you're taking on.

text:
and Steemit.

One of the most influential figures in the world of technology, Elon Musk, has taken his views to Twitter on a range of topics including renewable energy, electric cars, and space exploration. But the oft-controversial entrepreneur has faced a deluge of criticism from the public on the platform, prompting some to question his presence there.

If you’re thinking of cutting the cord, consider an alternative to Twitter like Mastodon and Steemit. Both are open-source social networks that are free and much more privacy-focused than Twitter.

Mastodon is a decentralized, open-source Twitter competitor launched in 2017 by German programmer Eugen Rochko. It is built on the same architecture as the popular microblogging site, with users’ posts appearing in their home timeline and replies and mentions forming threads. It also has “communities”, which are essentially public and private groups, which users can join and use to post and interact with other members.

A key difference between Mastodon and Twitter is that users’ posts are more widely spread and visible, due to its decentralized architecture. This means that your post can be seen by users in any part of the world, and not just those who are following you.

Steemit, on the other hand, is a blockchain-based social network that rewards users for creating and curating content. Like Mastodon, it is built on a decentralized platform and rewards users with “Steem” for posting and curating content.

Steemit has been around since 2016, but the platform has recently gained more attention following the introduction of a new cryptocurrency called STEEM Power. STEEM Power is essentially a loyalty program where users who hold a certain amount of STEEM tokens can earn additional tokens and rewards when they post or curate content.

Unlike Twitter, which relies heavily on algorithms to determine which content is seen and which is not, Steemit is powered by a democratic, blockchain-based system. Content is only visible to users who vote for it, which means that users can only see content that has earned the most votes.

However, unlike Mastodon, Steemit still has a long way to go before it can become a fully-fledged competitor to Twitter. The platform is still in its infancy and many of its features are lacking in comparison to Twitter, such as real-time conversations and hashtags.

For those who want to break free from the clutches of Twitter, Mastodon and Steemit offer an interesting alternative. While both platforms still have a long way to go before they can compete with the world’s largest social network, they are a much more private and secure alternative that could be a viable option for those looking to leave Twitter behind.

When it comes to business and problem-solving, sometimes your team can find itself in a tricky spot, unable to come up with a solution. This is especially true when the problem requires creative thinking or requires the team to look at things from a different perspective. In these situations, it can be beneficial to get the team to think outside the box to come up with a successful solution. Here are three tips for when your team needs to think outside the box.

1. Get the team to brainstorm

Brainstorming is one of the best ways to get a team to think outside the box. When brainstorming, the team should start by writing down a list of potential solutions, without any judgement or criticism. The ideas should be encouraged, no matter how outlandish or silly they may sound. This type of brainstorming can help to break down mental barriers and stimulate creative thinking. It also encourages collaboration, which can be a great way to build trust and create a space of innovation.

2. Encourage critical thinking

Another way to get a team to think outside the box is to encourage critical thinking. Critical thinking allows your team to analyze a problem from multiple angles. This helps them to see things from a different perspective, which can lead to more creative solutions. Encourage the team to ask probing questions and challenge assumptions, while also teaching them how to evaluate the available data. This will allow the team to make informed decisions and come up with effective solutions.

3. Set aside dedicated time for creativity

When it comes to thinking outside the box, time is your team’s biggest ally. When your team is stuck, set aside time for them to work on the problem, uninterrupted. This allows the team to really focus on the task at hand, without any distractions. During this time, the team can brainstorm, experiment, and explore different ideas and solutions. This can help them to come up with something creative and innovative, while also teaching them how to work together and think critically.

When your team needs to think outside the box, these three tips can help them to come up with a successful solution. Brainstorming, critical thinking, and setting aside dedicated time for creativity can all be great tools for getting your team to think in new and exciting ways. These techniques can help to break down mental barriers and encourage collaboration, ultimately allowing your team to find creative and effective solutions.

El viernes 2 de enero de 2023, Ucrania fue sacudida por otro día de violencia en su frontera con Rusia. Las fuerzas rusas se movieron hacia la región Donbás en Ucrania, continuando con lo que los líderes occidentales han llamado una nueva "acción militar agresiva" dirigida a acabar con la libertad de Ucrania. 

Una conferencia de prensa en Kiev el día 1 de enero presentó al primer ministro Volodymyr Groysman como el líder en lucha contra la agresión rusa. Prometió defender la soberanía de Ucrania de cualquier amenaza.

Las fuerzas rusas, apoyadas por agentes de inteligencia rusos, han estado tratando de avanzar hacia la región Donbás durante meses. Esto ha desencadenado una oleada de violencia con víctimas civiles y fue motivo de gran preocupación para los líderes occidentales, incluyendo al Presidente estadounidense Joe Biden, quien publicó un comunicado condenando la agresión rusa y exigiendo el fin de los ataques contra Ucrania.

Los ataques de las fuerzas rusas el día 2 de enero fueron el punto más alto de la violencia desde que el conflicto comenzó en el 2014. Los enfrentamientos se intensificaron desde el inicio de la semana y se intensificaron drásticamente durante el fin de semana, con Rusia bombardeando objetivos militares y civiles.

La resistencia de Ucrania ha sido obstinada y organizada, con las tropas de Ucrania luchando con éxito para detener el avance de las fuerzas rusas. Sin embargo, el creciente número de víctimas civiles ha creado una situación cada vez más preocupante.

En respuesta a los ataques de Rusia, la Unión Europea condenó la agresión y anunció una nueva ronda de sanciones con el objetivo de presionar al Gobierno ruso para que ponga fin al conflicto. Esta es la primera vez desde el 2014 que la UE ha impuesto sanciones a Rusia por su agresión militar.

Además, el presidente Biden ordenó el envío de ayuda humanitaria a Ucrania, incluyendo alimentos, medicamentos y suministros de emergencia. Esta decisión fue elogiada por la comunidad internacional y Ucrania, ya que ayuda a paliar la crisis humanitaria causada por la violencia.

En respuesta a las sanciones de la UE y la ayuda humanitaria, Rusia amenazó con desplegar más tropas a la frontera de Ucrania. El ministerio de exteriores ruso también ha amenazado con “tomar represalias” si hay nuevas sanciones.

A pesar de la amenaza rusa, la UE ha confirmado que continuará presionando a Rusia con nuevas sanciones, y que las relaciones entre Rusia y Ucrania continuarán deteriorándose si el conflicto no se resuelve pronto. Esto significa que la situación seguirá siendo crítica en los próximos días.

Mientras tanto, la comunidad internacional exige el fin de la violencia y el cese al fuego inmediato para evitar una mayor crisis humanitaria. Aunque los líderes de Ucrania se han mostrado optimistas de que el conflicto pueda solucionarse de forma pacífica, los continuos bombardeos rusos amenazan con frustrar sus esfuerzos.

En conclusión

text: You need a * lot * more power than a conventional boat . Which means bigger engines and higher fuel use , leaving less space for , y'know , stuff like weapons and crew accommodations and such . The maximum size is very small . It 's the square cube law , double the size and the foils can lift 4x as much ( wings have doubled in length and width ) but they now have to lift a boat weighing 8x as much ( hull has doubled in length , width , and height ) . It does n't take long before the hydrofoils become too big to be practical . That means it 's hard to dock them , they ca n't go in shallow water , resupply at sea is awful , etc . They 're often unstable and usually give a very rough ride , which is bad both for the crew and also the sensors / weapons ( and maintenance ) . So you really want to keep them in sheltered waters ( waves are bad for many types ) . But sheltered waters are usually shallow , which of course is doom to hydrofoils . Conventional small craft like the CB90 will happily do 35 kts , and can zoom through very shallow and restricted waters , right up onto a beach to deliver troops . Wave piercing catamarans will do 45 kts in the open ocean . A surface effect ship like the Skjold will do 60 kts , but again does n't have the super deep draft or hydrofoils sticking out either side , and AFAICT burns less fuel . But a hydrofoil patrol boat will do , what , 45kts ? A lot of small craft do best with the conventional design , because they 're great for riverine / amphibious warfare supporting landing teams . If you need extreme speed , you want a surface effect design . And if you want something bigger than ~400 tons , you 're looking for a wave piercer , which can do hydrofoil speeds at 4000 tons . And if you really need to get somewhere fast , we have aircraft .

text:
Aryna Sabalenka survived a late wobble to reach the quarter-finals of the Adelaide International on Wednesday, the Belarussian fighting back from a set down to beat Katerina Siniakova 3-6 6-4 6-4.

The world number seven had looked in control early on, holding serve for the first four games and creating two break points in the opening set. But the Czech veteran responded by immediately breaking the Sabalenka serve, and then doubled her advantage to take the set 6-3.

But Sabalenka refound her form in the second set, hitting crisper shots and more accurately finding the corners of the court as Siniakova struggled to keep up. The Belarussian took the second 6-4, and then broke the Siniakova serve twice in the decider to wrap up a hard-fought match.

“I’m really happy that I could come back after the first set,” said Sabalenka. “She was playing really well in the first set, she was playing aggressive and I was not feeling comfortable, so it was a little bit of an adjustment I needed to make.

“I was trying to be a little bit more aggressive, trying to make my shots deeper, and I think it worked. I was also trying to be more aggressive with my serve and it paid off in the end.”

Sabalenka’s reward for her win is a meeting with American Alison Riske in the quarter-finals. Riske had earlier beaten Nao Hibino of Japan 6-4 6-4 to set up the meeting with Sabalenka, the American winning a tight contest with some tight groundstrokes.

The American’s victory put an end to a run of three successive defeats at the hands of Hibino, the Japanese player having beaten her in all three of their previous meetings on the WTA Tour.

In other matches on Wednesday, Ons Jabeur of Tunisia fought back from a set down to beat Magda Linette of Poland 6-7(5) 6-4 6-2, while Switzerland’s Belinda Bencic also came from a set down to defeat Australia’s Astra Sharma 6-7(3) 6-3 6-3.

Earlier in the day, world number two Simona Halep was a convincing 6-2 6-3 winner over Madison Brengle of the United States, while Chinese fifth seed Zhang Shuai completed the quarter-final line-up with a hard-fought 6-4 6-7(8) 6-2 victory over Russia’s Ekaterina Alexandrova.

Sabalenka, Halep and Zhang Shuai will all now be in action in the quarter-finals on Friday, while Riske, Jabeur and Bencic will fight it out in the remaining two matches.

“It’s great to be in the quarter-finals,” said Halep. “I’ve played some really good tennis this week, and it feels great to be in the quarter-finals. I’m looking forward to seeing what the rest of the tournament has in store for me.”

The semi-finals and the final of the Adelaide International will take place on Sunday.

text: The Supremacy Clause is a provision in the United States Constitution that establishes that the federal Constitution, and federal law generally, take precedence over state laws, and even state constitutions. This means that if there is a conflict between federal and state laws, the federal law will be supreme and will be applied. However, the Supremacy Clause does not mean that federal laws can override the Constitution itself. The Constitution is the supreme law of the land, and it establishes the powers of the federal government and limits on those powers. Congress, as one of the branches of the federal government, does have the power to pass laws, but those laws must be consistent with the Constitution. If a law passed by Congress is found to be in conflict with the Constitution, it can be challenged in court and potentially be struck down as unconstitutional. So, in summary, a law passed by Congress can't directly override the Constitution, but it can be found to be in conflict with the Constitution and be struck down by the courts. The only way to change the Constitution itself is through the amendment process, which requires the approval of two-thirds of both houses of Congress or a convention called for by two-thirds of the states, and ratification by three-fourths of the states.

Out on the pristine Indiana waters, record-breaking catches can easily be made.

In mid-January, a new Indiana state record for burbot (Lota lota) was set when a 9.19-pound burbot was caught in the Patoka River in southwestern Indiana. It was the largest burbot to ever be reeled in in the Hoosier State.

The fish was landed by Brian Hines, a professional angler who’s been fishing in Indiana and other nearby states for 15 years.

“I was out fishing with friends and we had been casting crankbaits and topwaters around, but nothing was really happening,” Hines said.

“So I decided to switch to bottom fishing and that’s when I hooked into the record-breaking burbot.”

Hines immediately knew it was a big fish, but he had no idea it was a record-breaker.

“I had no idea how big it was until I got it in the boat and we weighed it,” he said.

The record-breaking burbot had a length of 26 inches and a girth of 17.5 inches. It’s the fourth-largest burbot ever recorded in Indiana. The current state record for burbot is a 9.80-pounder caught on the Wabash River in December, 2014.

“It was an awesome experience and definitely one I won’t forget,” Hines said.

Burbot, also known as freshwater cod or lawyer, are a species of codfish found in the Northern Hemisphere. They inhabit cool and deep waters of the Atlantic, Pacific, and Arctic Oceans.

In Indiana, burbot are found in the Maumee, Ohio, Wabash, St. Joseph, and Patoka rivers. They’re most commonly caught by anglers fishing the deep pools and areas of slow-moving water in rivers.

In order to keep a record-breaking burbot, anglers must submit an application to the Indiana Department of Natural Resources (IDNR). The fish must be weighed and measured on a certified scale and photograph must be taken as proof.

The current state record for burbot was also caught in the Patoka River. It was reeled in by Michael Mayo in December, 2014. Mayo’s burbot weighed 9.80 pounds and had a length of 24.5 inches.

Although record-breaking catches don’t happen every day, the waters of Indiana can easily produce big fish. Anglers can easily find several species of fish, including bass, walleye, catfish, and even muskie.

So, if you’re looking for a chance to break an Indiana record, get out and start fishing. You never know what you’ll catch.

text: Symbolic artificial intelligence (AI) is a subfield of AI that focuses on the use of symbolic representations and logic-based methods to solve problems. It is also sometimes referred to as "classical AI" or "good old-fashioned AI (GOFAI)."    In symbolic AI, problems are solved by manipulating symbols according to a set of rules. The symbols represent concepts or entities in the problem domain, and the rules represent the relationships between those concepts or entities. For example, a symbolic AI system might be designed to solve a puzzle by representing the different pieces of the puzzle as symbols and using rules to manipulate those symbols and find a solution.    Symbolic AI systems are often based on first-order logic, which allows them to represent and reason about the properties of objects and the relationships between them. This makes them well-suited for tasks that require logical reasoning and problem-solving, such as natural language processing, planning, and theorem proving.    However, symbolic AI systems have some limitations. They can be difficult to design and implement, and they may require a large amount of human-generated knowledge to be encoded into the system. In addition, they can be inflexible and may not be able to handle uncertainty or handle tasks that require a lot of data or sensory input.    Today, symbolic AI is often used in combination with other AI techniques, such as machine learning and neural networks, in order to improve their performance and overcome some of their limitations.

text: Selling put options can be a way for a retiree to generate income, but it is important to understand the risks and potential downsides of this strategy.When you sell a put option, you are agreeing to buy a certain asset (such as a stock) at a predetermined price (the strike price) at a later date (the expiration date). In return, you receive a premium payment from the buyer of the option. If the market price of the asset falls below the strike price, the buyer of the option may choose to exercise their right to sell the asset to you at the strike price, and you will be required to purchase the asset at that price.One potential risk of selling put options is that you may end up having to buy the asset at a higher price than its market value, which could result in a loss. This is especially true if the market value of the asset falls significantly below the strike price. In addition, there is always the risk that the market value of the asset could rise above the strike price, in which case you would not receive the premium payment.Overall, selling put options can be a risky strategy, and it may not be suitable for everyone, especially those who are risk-averse or have limited investment capital. It is important to carefully consider your risk tolerance, financial goals, and other personal circumstances before deciding whether this strategy is right for you. As with any investment, it is always a good idea to consult with a financial professional before making any decisions.

text:
North Korea shocked the world on Tuesday, November 17 when it launched a suspected intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM), its second test this month.

The missile, reported to be an ICBM, was launched from the northwest of North Korea and flew for about 800 kilometers before landing off the coast of Japan. It is the second test launch of an ICBM this month, and the first in almost two years.

The launch provoked a strong reaction from the international community. South Korea's President Moon Jae-in condemned the test and said that it was a "serious challenge" to regional security. President Donald Trump issued a statement saying the U.S. would "take care of it," and that "all options are on the table." Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe also condemned the test and said that the launch violated international law and posed a "grave threat" to his country.

North Korea's ICBM launches have been prohibited since 2006, when the United Nations Security Council imposed sanctions on the country. Despite this, North Korea has continued to pursue its nuclear and missile programs. This latest test serves to show the country's willingness to break international agreements and pursue its weapons programs despite the threat of sanctions.

The United Nations Security Council is expected to meet and discuss the launch, and will likely impose additional sanctions on North Korea. China, North Korea's biggest ally, also condemned the test and urged the country to stop its nuclear and missile programs.

The launch of the ICBM is especially concerning because it shows that North Korea is continuing to develop its weapons capabilities. If the missile had been fired at a different angle, it could have been capable of reaching the continental United States. This adds to the already high tensions between the U.S. and North Korea, and could further destabilize the region.

The launch also highlights the failure of the United States to respond effectively to North Korea's nuclear and missile programs. The Trump administration has so far failed to impose meaningful sanctions on North Korea or to come up with a plan to deter the country from pursuing its weapons programs. The administration has also been criticized for its handling of the nuclear crisis, with critics arguing that its strategy of "maximum pressure" has failed to deter North Korea.

In response to the launch, the U.S. and South Korea conducted joint military exercises in the Sea of Japan. The U.S. also sent two strategic bombers to the region as a show of force. The bomber flights, along with additional sanctions, are aimed at pressuring North Korea to stop its nuclear and missile programs.

Ultimately, however, the solution to the crisis will require a diplomatic solution. The U.S. and its allies must work together to find a way to convince North Korea to give up its nuclear and missile programs. Until then, tensions between the U.S. and North Korea will likely remain high, and the threat of further ICBM tests will loom.

text:
MEXICO CITY (AP) — The sight of a natural spring-fed well spouting flames and thick, black smoke drew hundreds of protesters to the outskirts of Mexico City Tuesday, in what experts believe is the first reported case of a burning water source in Mexico.

Residents of Cuajimoloyas, a mostly indigenous community around 120 miles south of Mexico City, awoke early Tuesday morning to find their main water source, a hand-dug well, engulfed in flames and spewing out thick smoke.

“It was like something out of a horror movie,” said Yolanda González, who first spotted the flames shortly after sunrise. “The flames were reaching at least 8 feet in the air and you could smell gas in the air. It was terrifying.”

Local authorities believe the well was set on fire intentionally, and some residents point the finger at local oil and gas companies operating nearby.

“We’ve had problems with these companies in the past and I’m sure that they had something to do with this,” said González. “They don’t care about us or our environment. All they care about is money.”

Other locals, however, say that the well could have caught fire due to natural causes, such as underground gas pockets.

The burning well has cast a spotlight on Mexico’s ongoing water crisis, which has been particularly acute since the country began to suffer from prolonged drought in the early 2020s. In rural areas like Cuajimoloyas, access to clean and safe water is often limited to wells, some of them more than a century old.

As news of the well spread throughout Mexico, so did calls for protests. Hundreds of students and activists turned up at the well site, many chanting slogans such as “the water belongs to the people!” The crowds remained in the area late into the night, though local authorities prevented the well from being extinguished.

The federal government has promised to investigate the cause of the fire and to take measures to ensure that similar incidents are prevented in the future. Environmental experts warn, however, that water contamination remains a severe threat, especially as Mexico’s oil and gas industry continues to grow.

“This is a stark reminder of the many dangers posed by the oil and gas industry and its operations near water sources,” said Carlos Fuentes, director of the Mexican Association of Environmentalists. “Oil spills, chemical leaks and other contaminants can put nearby wells and rivers at risk and put local communities in danger.”

Residents of Cuajimoloyas are demanding more action from the government to ensure the safety of their water sources.

“This is our lifeblood,” said González. “The government needs to do more to protect it. It’s the least they can do.”

Lowering / raising tools into a hold ... grab a bag , line and tie up a few knots . Need to wash a tank with a portable hose and machine ... Some line and a timber hitch are all you need . These numbers are usually generated using a mathematical formula, and the sequence of numbers that is produced will be different each time the code is run.

Another way to generate pseudorandom numbers is to use something called a "random seed." A random seed is a starting number that is used to generate a sequence of pseudorandom numbers. If you use the same random seed every time, you'll get the same sequence of pseudorandom numbers. But if you use a different random seed each time, you'll get a different sequence of numbers.

It's late November, and Wall Street's focus is on the political drama playing out in Washington following the midterm elections. As lawmakers jostle for control of the House, investors can expect to see a post-midterms stock market rally, but it could be muted if underlying economic data point to rising inflation and the possibility of recession.

The stock market has historically performed well after midterm elections. But this time around, inflation and recession fears could temper the optimism and make this post-midterm rally a bit more muted than usual.

The consumer price index, a key gauge of inflation, has been rising at a steady clip this year and is now at a two-year high. Core inflation, which strips out volatile food and energy costs, has also been on the rise in recent months and is now at a five-year high. The increases, while modest, are enough to rattle investors and stoke fears of a possible recession.

The yield curve has also been flattening in recent months, a sign that the market expects economic growth to slow down. An inverted yield curve is often seen as a harbinger of recession, as it indicates that investors are becoming increasingly worried about future growth prospects.

The Federal Reserve has been increasing interest rates, making it more expensive for companies and consumers to borrow money. While higher interest rates help to curb inflation, they can also slow economic growth by making it more expensive for companies to hire workers, purchase new equipment, or expand their operations.

The central bank has been carefully watching the economy and is expected to continue raising interest rates gradually to keep inflation in check. However, if the Fed raises rates too quickly, it could push the economy into a recession.

Adding to the uncertainty is the political situation in Washington. The midterm elections were seen as a referendum on President Donald Trump's first two years in office, and the results have split Congress between Democrats and Republicans. With lawmakers split on key issues, it could be difficult to pass legislation that could stimulate economic growth.

All of these factors could contribute to a more muted post-midterms stock market rally. Investors will be looking to see how the economic data plays out over the next few months before deciding if the bull market is intact or if the rally has run out of steam.

The economic picture is far from clear, but what is certain is that any post-midterms rally will be affected by inflation and recession worries. Investors should keep an eye on the economic data and the politics in Washington in the weeks and months ahead, as both will play a major role in determining the strength of the stock market rally.

Tesla (TSLA) has always been an enigma to investors. Many love the company and its innovative spirit and trend-setting products, but some remain unconvinced of the company's ability to turn a profit. This divide, along with the risky nature of tech stocks and Tesla's declining stock price, has left many investors scratching their heads. But according to Wharton professor and noted finance analyst, Jeremy Siegel, there is a clear, consistent explanation for the selloff that puts it in a familiar context.

In a recent blog post, Siegel said that Tesla's stock price had dropped due to investor expectations that have outstripped reality, a problem that parallels that of Warren Buffett's investments in the '90s.

"Back in the 90s, Warren Buffett was buying huge stakes in a number of US companies," Siegel wrote. "However, he faced massive expectations for those investments. The shares of the companies he bought rose sharply, but not nearly to the level that the market had priced in his expectations. The same can be said of Tesla today."

Siegel argues that investors have piled into the stock expecting that Tesla would become one of the most important and valuable companies in the world. Unfortunately, he believes this is not feasible without significant advances in the car maker's production capabilities and technology. Without these advancements, Tesla will not be able to deliver on investors' expectations, and the stock will fail to maintain its current price.

"Without the prospect of Tesla becoming the Amazon, Microsoft, or Apple of the automotive world, it is difficult to see the stock sustaining its current valuation levels," Siegel wrote.

This is not to say that Tesla is a bad stock to own, just that investors should manage their expectations and understand that the company's future prospects are more limited than the sky-high valuations suggest.

Siegel's take on Tesla's stock price decline is echoed by a number of Wall Street analysts. Many believe that the stock's lofty valuation reflects irrational exuberance more than its business prospects. Indeed, in the past year, several well-known analysts such as Bank of America, JPMorgan, and Goldman Sachs have downgraded their ratings on the company.

Ultimately, it appears that Tesla is a high risk, high reward stock. If the company can follow through on its ambitious plans, then the stock could reach new heights. However, there is a very real risk that the company may fail to meet investor expectations, resulting in a prolonged period of disappointing returns. As Siegel has made clear, it's important to be mindful of these risks when investing in Tesla stock.

text: Pinyin is actually a standardized system for writing Chinese using the Roman alphabet, and it is widely used in China for teaching Chinese as a second language, transcribing proper nouns and place names, and as a tool for inputting Chinese characters on computers and phones.  However, Pinyin is not used as the primary written form of Chinese. Chinese characters (also known as Hanzi or Kanji in Japanese) are the primary written form of Chinese and have a long history dating back over 3,000 years. They are still used today because they are an important part of Chinese culture and history, and they are also very efficient for written communication.  One of the main reasons that Pinyin is not used as the primary written form of Chinese is that it cannot fully represent the sounds and meanings of Chinese words. Chinese characters, on the other hand, can convey the full meaning and pronunciation of a word in a single character. For example, the Chinese character for "water" is 水, which is pronounced "shui" in Mandarin. Pinyin cannot represent the meaning of the character, only the pronunciation.  Additionally, replacing Chinese characters with Pinyin as the primary written form of Chinese would be a massive undertaking that would involve changing the way that Chinese is taught in schools, updating dictionaries and other reference materials, and potentially requiring people to learn a new writing system. It would also be difficult to determine a standard way to represent the many different regional accents and dialects of Chinese using the Roman alphabet.  In summary, while Pinyin is a useful tool for learning Chinese and transcribing proper nouns, it is not used as the primary written form of Chinese because it cannot fully represent the sounds and meanings of Chinese words, and replacing Chinese characters with Pinyin would be a major undertaking.

text: This would create a situation where people could save money by purchasing insurance only when they needed healthcare rather than on a regular basis . After all , why pay for the insurance when I 'm healthy if can just buy insurance if I start to feel sick ? Because fewer healthy people are signing up ( people who would be cheaper for the insurance company ) and the sick ones are still able to ( expensive ) , the average expenditures the insurance company has to make for each person goes up . So they raise their rates in response . More healthy people drop out sinc , forgoing the more expensive insurance since they do n't need it and can buy it later . And costs go up again , so prices go up again , so more healthy people drop out again . And so on , until prices get so high that it 's effectively not an insurance system , just sick people paying a lot of money for healthcare . If you can only sign up for health insurance once a year , it makes this much harder to do . What if you got sick three months after open enrollment ? You would be without insurance when you needed it . So you 're more likely to buy the insurance before you get sick , lowering average costs and making a true insurance system more tenable . There are other ways around it , like exclusions for pre - existing conditions and waiting periods , but these are potentially more problematic than open enrollment periods .

The year 2021 was a turbulent one for the world. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, the face of the planet changed drastically, and people from all walks of life felt the impact. But as a reminder of the innate resilience of the human spirit, 2021 marked a number of remarkable successes as well. 

In this January/February 2023 issue, The Atlantic will be looking back at the year 2021, exploring the many areas that made us proud, and examining the numerous lessons that were learned. We will be exploring the complex topics of economic upheaval, government action, public discourse, and technological progress in the face of global challenges. 

This issue will open with a look at how governments around the world rose to the challenges presented by the pandemic and initiated sweeping policy changes that are helping to rebuild the global economy. We will explore the various approaches taken by nations such as the United States, China, Japan, and the European Union, and assess the impact of these measures on countries’ economies. 

We will take a look at how the public discourse around the pandemic has evolved in 2021 and the impact that it has had on how policy is formed and implemented. We will also be examining the role of technology in the fight against the virus and its potential long-term implications. 

In addition, we will be exploring the increasing importance of the commons—the various public spaces, networks, and services that are shared by the entire global community. We will be looking at how the commons has been used to create a more equitable society, and how it has allowed people from all walks of life to come together and collaborate on solutions to shared challenges. 

In the wake of the pandemic, the world has seen an unprecedented level of environmental awareness and activism, and this issue will take a deep dive into these efforts. We will be highlighting how grassroots movements have been instrumental in creating public pressure for policy change, and how the influence of the commons has opened up the debate to include a diverse range of voices. 

Finally, this issue will explore the potential for a more connected and collaborative global future. We will look at how artificial intelligence, robotics, and distributed ledger technology are being used to create opportunities for individuals and communities around the world. We will examine the potential impact of these technologies and discuss their implications for the larger global economy. 

We hope that this January/February 2023 issue of The Atlantic will provide an opportunity to reflect on the incredible progress made in 2021 and serve as a reminder of the importance of embracing the commons in times of crisis. As we look forward to an uncertain future, we hope that the lessons learned in 2021 will help us build a more equitable and connected world.
